facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 311 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 311 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 31, 1955 of Travancore Cochin High Court, Ernakulam in Original Petition No. 75 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1955, of the Travancore Cochin High Court, Ernakulam, in Original Petition No. 75 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR, J. on December 13, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

facts.text: Respondent is a limited company which owns a spinning mill at Alwaye.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a limited companypany which owns a spinning mills at Alwaye.

facts.text: Respondent commenced business in January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It companymenced business in January, 1951,

facts.text: Respondent's first accounting year ended on December 31, 1951; relevant assessment year is 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: and its first accounting year ended on December 31, 1951, and the relevant assessment year is 1952-53.

facts.text: Respondent filed return showing income of Rs. 3,21,284 without accounting for s. 15C deduction.

anchor.surface_text: It filed its return showing an income Rs. 3,21,284 without taking into account the amount allowable under s. 15C of the Act.

facts.text: On February 2, 1953, Income-tax Officer determined respondent's net assessable income at Rs. 1,47,083 after deducting Rs. 1,79,081 under s. 15C.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1953, the net assessable income of the respondent was determined at Rs. 1,47,083 after deducting Rs. 1,79,081 under s. 15C.

facts.text: Respondent declared dividend of Rs. 4,72,415 attracting additional income tax under s. 2 of Finance Act, 1952 read with Part B proviso ii of First Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent however declared a dividend of Rs. 4,72,415 which attracted the application of s. 2 of the Finance Act, 1952, read with Part B, proviso  ii  of First Schedule

facts.text: Income-tax Officer overlooked the additional income tax liability due to dividend.

anchor.surface_text: and thus it became liable to the payment of additional income tax and this fact was overlooked by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 35 and by order dated January 25, 1954 rectified error and imposed additional tax at one anna in the rupee.

anchor.surface_text: After giving numberice under s. 35 of the Act, the Income-tax Officer by an order dated January 25, 1954, rectified this error and imposed an additional tax at the rate of one anna in the rupee.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer discovered error in rate and by order dated August 12, 1954 rectified to 5 annas in a rupee.

anchor.surface_text: He later discovered that this was also erroneous and the rate should have been 5 annas in a rupee. By an order dated August 12, 1954, he rectified the error.

facts.text: Respondent deposited only Rs. 5,000 as advance income tax under s. 18A and became liable to penal interest under s. 18A(8).

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 18A, advance income tax had to be paid and the respondent companypany had deposited only Rs. 5,000 and therefore became liable to penal interest under s. 18A 8  of the Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rectified omission to impose penal interest by the same order.

anchor.surface_text: By the same order this omission to impose penal interest was companyrected and this error was thus rectified.

facts.text: Respondent filed revision under s. 33A(2) to Commissioner of Income-tax which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the respondent companypany went in revision under s. 33A 2  to the Commissioner of Income-tax but the revision was dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 of Constitution in High Court of Kerala claiming s. 35 not applicable and no additional tax on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent companypany filed a petition in the High Court of Kerala under Art. 226 of the Constitution on the ground that s. 35 of the Act did number apply and that on the merits additional tax companyld number be imposed.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated October 31, 1955 held orders without jurisdiction and granted writ of certiorari quashing them.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment dated October 31, 1955 held that the orders made were without jurisdiction and therefore granted a writ of certiorari quashing the orders

facts.text: Income-tax Officer brought appeal pursuant to certificate of High Court of Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal pursuant to a certificate of the High Court of Kerala against the judgment and order of that companyrt

facts.text: N. Kripal and D. Gupta appeared for the appellant; Sardar Bahadur for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: N. Kripal and D. Gupta, for the appellant. Sardar Bahadur, for the respondent.

facts.text: High Court held levy of penal interest under s. 18A(8) for failure to make advance deposit under s. 18A(3) was without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the levy of penal interest under s. 18A 8  of the Act for failure to make advance deposit under s. 18A 3  was also without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal concerns applicability of s. 35 of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the question for decision is the applicability of s. 35 of the Indian Income-tax Act  hereinafter termed the Act .

the respondent companypany filed a petition in the High Court of Kerala under Art. 226 of the Constitution on the ground that s. 35 of the Act did number apply and that on the merits additional tax companyld number be imposed.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court seem to have fallen into an error in equating the language and scope of s. 35 of the Act with that of O. 47, r. 1, Civil Procedure Code. The language of the two is different

arguments.claim: Under s.35, ITO can examine record including evidence to discover mistake (citing Maharana Mills Pvt Ltd v ITO)

anchor.surface_text: because according to s. 35 of the Act which provides for rectification of mistakes the power is given to the various income-tax authorities within four years from the date of any assessment passed by them to rectify any mistake apparent from the record

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, can, under s. 35 of the Act, examine the record and if he discovers that he has made a mistake he can rectify the error and the error which can be companyrected may be an error of fact or of law. The restrictive operation of the power of review under 0. 47 R. 1,

holdings.text: Section 35 of the Income-tax Act is not analogous to Order 47 Rule 1 CPC; its language and scope are different, allowing rectification of any mistake apparent from the record within 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court seem to have fallen into an error in equating the language and scope of s. 35 of the Act with that of O. 47, r. 1, Civil Procedure Code. The language of the two is different because according to s. 35 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison shows different wording; s.35 uses 'apparent from the record' vs CPC 'apparent on the face'; cites prior SC cases distinguishing.

holdings.text: Under s.35, Income-tax authorities can examine the entire record including evidence to discover and rectify mistakes of fact or law, subject to notice and hearing if enhancing assessment.

anchor.surface_text: because according to s. 35 of the Act which provides for rectification of mistakes the power is given to the various income-tax authorities within four years from the date of any assessment passed by them to rectify any mistake apparent from the record

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC precedents Maharana Mills (written down value error) and Venkatachalam (retrospective amendment error); power not limited to non-argumentative errors.

holdings.text: The restrictive operation of review power under O.47 R.1 CPC does not apply to s.35 IT Act; ITO's order rectifying additional tax omission was within jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, can, under s. 35 of the Act, examine the record and if he discovers that he has made a mistake he can rectify the error and the error which can be corrected may be an error of fact or of law. The restrictive operation of the power of review under 0. 47 R. 1,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies broader s.35 scope to facts: overlooking additional tax liability due to dividend (Finance Act s.2 + Sch Part B prov ii) is rectifiable mistake from record.

holdings.text: Section 18A(8) is mandatory; where no advance tax paid as required, penal interest calculated per s.18A(6) must be added to regular assessment; omission is rectifiable under s.35.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to s. 18A  8  also the learned Judges have misdirected themselves because that section is mandatory. It provides- S. 18A 8  Where, on making the regular assessment,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: mandatory language requires addition on regular assessment; failure to do so is apparent mistake from record.

holdings.text: The High Court's order quashing ITO's rectification orders under writ of certiorari was erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the order of the High Court was erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: High Court erred in narrow interpretation of s.35 akin to CPC review, overlooking precedents and mandatory provisions.

precedents.citation: Maharana Mills Private Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Porbandar 1

anchor.surface_text: Maharana Mills Private Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Porbandar 1 has laid down the scope of s. 35 at p. 358 in the following words- The power under section 35 is numberdoubt limited to rectification of mistakes which are apparent from the record.

precedents.case_name: Maharana Mills Private Ltd v Income-tax Officer, Porbandar
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of s. 35 of the Income-tax Act: power to rectify mistakes apparent from the record; ITO can examine record and evidence; mistake not requiring argument
precedents.cited_holding: The power under section 35 is undoubt limited to rectification of mistakes which are apparent from the record. A mistake contemplated by this section is not one which is to be discovered as a result of an argument but it is open to the Income-tax Officer to examine the record including the evidence and if he discovers any mistake he is entitled to rectify the error...

precedents.citation: M. K. Venkatachalam v. Bombay Dyeing Manufacturing Co. Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: In an earlier case M. K. Venkatachalam v. Bombay Dyeing Manufacturing Co. Ltd.  2  where as a consequence of a subsequent amendment of the law having retrospective effect, the Income-tax Officer reduced the amount of interest under s. 18A(5) of the Act...

precedents.case_name: M K Venkatachalam v Bombay Dyeing Manufacturing Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Mistake apparent from record includes misapplication of law due to retrospective amendment
precedents.cited_holding: it was held that it was a case of error apparent from the record... he had to read the principal Act as containing the inserted proviso as from April 1, 1952.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Elphinstone Spinning Weaving Mills Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Elphinstone Spinning Weaving Mills Co. Ltd.  1  and similar cases reported as Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Jalgaon Electric Supply Co. Ltd.1  and Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.  3  but the facts of those cases were different.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Elphinstone Spinning Weaving Mills Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Applicability of proviso ii of Part B of First Schedule of Finance Act 1952

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Jalgaon Electric Supply Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Jalgaon Electric Supply Co. Ltd.1  and Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.  3  but the facts of those cases were different. In the first case there was nototal income and the Finance Act was not applicable in that case.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City v Jalgaon Electric Supply Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Applicability of proviso ii of Part B of First Schedule of Finance Act 1952
precedents.cited_holding: there was no profit in any preceding year and therefore the fiction failed because it postulates that there should be undistributed profits of one or more years immediately preceding the previous year.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. 3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.  3  but the facts of those cases were different. In the first case there was nototal income... In the third case also the Finance Act was inapplicable because the additional tax was not properly laid upon the total income...

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City v Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Applicability of proviso ii of Part B of First Schedule of Finance Act 1952
precedents.cited_holding: the Finance Act was inapplicable because the additional tax was not properly laid upon the total income and what was actually taxed was never a part of the total income of the previous year.
